div.p: Illustrated literary annual. The first four volumes, 1824-27, were published by Lupton Relfe. Another seventeen volumes, for the years 1828-44 (i.e., published "for" the New Year's holiday seasons 1828-44, the volumes themselves produced and released late in the previous year, 1827-43), were published by Smith, Elder, & Company (Harris, Forget Me Not, 124-26, 323-34; Faxon, Literary Annuals, 93-95). While not the first publication to sponsor Ruskinʼs writing, Friendshipʼs Offering was the first widely distributed venue for his poetry, beginning with “Saltzburg” and “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, included in the volume for 1835 (released in October or November 1834). Thereafter, Friendshipʼs Offering remained a reliable showcase for Ruskinʼs verse, which appeared in each annual volume until the series' demise.

div.head: The Founding of the Annual by Lupton Relfe
div.p: The first volume of Friendshipʼs Offering appeared with the date 1824, published by a bookseller in Cornhill Street, Lupton Relfe. The Ruskin family had some awareness of this early stage of the annual, since the volume for 1825, Relfe's second volume in the series, came into the family library with an inscription to Mary Richardson (1815-49), Ruskin's cousin who first came to Camberwell to live with the family in 1827 (Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 122 [no. 953]; and for specific features of the 1825 Friendship's Offering, see Harris, "Feminizing the Textual Body", 601-2, 611). As Katherine D. Harris remarks, Relfe's first volume, for 1824, appeared only one year after the very first of the British annuals, Forget Me Not (1823), was released by the firm of Rudolf Ackermann in 1822 for the holiday season of 1822–23. Harris transcribes the preface of this debut volume of Friendship's Offering and details the volume's contents, revealing a derivative and miscellaneous assemblage that exposes Relfe as aspiring only to mimic and capitalize on Ackermann's achievement. He had formed no clear conception of his production, which mixes features of the literary annual with the almanac and the eighteenth‐century “pocket book” (Harris, Forget Me Not, 124-25, 280; and “Chronological Index of British and American Literary Annual Titles” in Harris, ed., “Forget Me Not” Archive; and for more on the history and development of the literary annual as a publishing phenomenon, see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books, and and Samuel Rogers: The Publication History of Rogersʼs Italy).

A low estimation of the beginnings of Friendship's Offering was formed as early as 1858, in a survey of the heyday of the annuals, which declared Relfeʼs production “unpromising” (“The Annuals of Former Days”, 496). To become successful, Friendshipʼs Offering needed to shed the miscellaneous features derived from its early models and to define its niche in the market. Its shortcomings were acknowledged by the editor, T. K. Hervey (1799–1859), in his prefatory remarks for the 1826 volume: pleading “difficulties” that arose from the publication having, only “very recently, come into the present Editorʼs hands" (Hervey had in fact edited the title since 1824), he announced "a view to an entire change in . . . [the annual's] character and plan”. He proposed “alterations . . . consist[ing] in the removal of all those features which marked it as more peculiarly adapted for one season of the year than another”, with the aim instead of “combining, with the increased beauty of its embellishments, a high literary character” (Hervey, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1826], v, vi).

With this 1826 volume, the hodgepodge of features such as blank calendar pages, informational charts, and sheet music that, according to Harris, had cluttered the first volume, did fall away (Harris, Forget Me Not, 126). In order "to create a more marketable" item, Frienship's Offering became a "completely prefabricated book of printed memories", albeit at the cost of the "album-like qualities" that allowed both the giver and the recipient to personalize the volume with inscriptions (Harris, "Feminizing the Textual Body", 607). The improved "literary character" promised by Hervey is adumbrated in the 1826 volume with contributions by the likes of L.E.L. (Letitia Landon, 1802-38), James Montgomery (1771-1854), and Ruskin's future Camberwell schoolmaster, the Reverend Thomas Dale (1797-1870).

div.head: Illustration in the Relfe Annual
div.p: The 1826 volume is embellished by few engravings compared to the later, robustly pictorial standards for the annual under the Smith, Elder propretorship. The pairings of picture and poem are marked, however, by a consistently Romantic-era transformation of the ut pictura poesis aesthetic, which Roy Park characterizes as an abandonment of the worn pictorialism of the eighteenth century in favor of a view of the sister arts as "twin facets of a unified poetic experience" (Park, "'Ut Pictura Poesis': The Nineteenth-Century Aftermath", 156). Ekphrastic poems in the volume pay tribute to a shared poetic experience. For example, in a poem accompanying an engraving of a Claude landscape, the speaker declines to engage in the traditional contest between poet and painter, the rivalry of the Renaissance paragone: "I feel / No envy of thy noble art, / . . . which, unto outward sense, / Speaks in a language so refined" (Bernard Barton, "'Am I, Too, in Arcadia?'"). A similar strategy is adopted in a poem by L.E.L. to accompany an engraving of Honors Rendered to Raphael on his Deathbed (1806) by the French painter in the Troubadour style, Pierre Nolasque Bergeret (1782-1863). Awarding immortality to the sister art, L.E.L.'s speaker marvels how, despite the "face of death" that leaves Raphael "paler and colder than the marble bust", there can be no departure of the artist's "soul" that "leave[s] its influence on the heart!" (L.E.L., "Raphael's Death-Bed").

Feebler pictures are showcased in the 1826 volume with engravings after Richard Westall (1765-1836), including the frontispiece which illustrates a poem by the editor; however, the intrinsic merit of the pictures probably mattered less to consumers of Friendship's Offering than did recognition of Westall's reputation, who was known for his numerous illustrations of Romantic-era poets and for his evocative portraits of Byron. As an 1824 tribute to Westall effused, his work embodied the "poetic" spirit unifying the sister arts: he was the ideal portraitist of Byron, since "Thou saw'st the poet, with a poet's eye, / And hence a poet's mind could well descry, / For thou, to graphic genius not confin'd, / Can'st boast the pow'rs of a poetic mind" (John Taylor [1757-1832], "Lines on the Portrait of the Late Lord Byron, Painted by Richard Westall, Esq. RA") (Hervey, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1826], 47-48, 73-75; Taylor quoted in Westall, "Richard Westall's Labours of Love", 60).

div.head: The Takeover of the Annual by Smith, Elder, & Company
div.p: Relfeʼs final volume of Friendshipʼs Offering was 1827 (released presumably in late 1826), edited by Hervey and B. E. Pote (“Editors and Publishers of British Literary Annuals, 1823–31”, in Harris, Forget Me Not, 324). In 1827, the publication was taken over by the relatively young stationery and bookselling firm of Smith, Elder, & Company, which had recently moved to no. 65 Cornhill, near Relfe. By 1827, Smith, Elderʼs publishing ventures had been modest, but they raised their ambitions with the acquisition of Friendshipʼs Offering, not only in the scope of the undertaking but also in creative response to the market. Under their custodianship, Friendshipʼs Offering became a distinctive contribution to this characteristic early‐Victorian type of publication. Its subtitle was expanded to A Literary Album, and Christmas and New Yearʼs Present, and the annual improved strikingly in its material appeal. Sales rose, eventually peaking at ten thousand copies per year, assuring the fortunes of Smith, Elder as a publisher. (As a comparison, Ackermannʼs Forget Me Not in some years achieved twenty thousand. See the account of Smith, Elder, & Company in Bell, “Smith, George Murray [1824–1901]”, the biography of the son of George Smith (1789–1846), who founded the firm along with Alexander Elder (1790–1876); see also Ford, Ackermann, 65.)

Smith, Elder released their first volume of the annual in time for the 1827–28 holiday season. The volume for 1828 was edited by Charles Knight (1791–1873), the future publisher for the Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge. Knight, then struggling to establish himself in London publishing, was complimented by the Monthly Review on his success with the 1828 volume: "considering the advanced period of the season when his duties commenced", Knight had collected "a sufficient number" of literary pieces "readable enough . . . to wile away an hour or two of a winter's evening". Faint praise, but the reviewer was impressed by the quality of illustration: the plates were "really very creditable to the publishers", their "subjects . . . selected with great judgment" and "engraved in a chaste, artist-like style" (Unsigned review of The Keepsake for 1828; Friendship's Offering for 1828; and The Christmas-Box [1828], 71).

div.head: Illustration in the Smith, Elder Annual
div.p: The quality of illustration was the special care of one partner in the young firm, Alexander Elder (1790–1876). According to the biographer of the firm, Leonard Huxley, Elder was interested in art, and aspired to produce elegantly illustrated publications (House of Smith Elder, 10; and see Smith, Elder, & Company). It was not only the quality of the engravings but also their character, which was influenced presumably by Elder as well as by the editor who succeeded Knight, Thomas Pringle. A poet and an activist in the Anti‐Slavery Society, Pringle had recently returned from disappointed hopes of advancement in South Africa. He was also a native Scotsman like the proprietors, and the pictorial embellishments along with the literary contributions to Friendship's Offering took on a decided Caledonian emphasis. The change was doubtless a pleasurable one to John James Ruskin, who made Pringle a regular visitor to Herne Hill. It was Pringle, accordingly, who later introduced Ruskin to the fashionable literary world as the author “J.R.”

Under Knight, the 1828 volume of Frienship's Offering featured fewer than five contributions by Scottish writers, including Pringle and Allan Cunningham (1784-1842). The 1829 volume, under Pringle, offered over thirty contributions by Scots--more than a third of the total--including such poems as "The Highland Hunter's Coronach, "On Leaving Scotland", such tales as "The Covenanters: A Scottish Traditionary Tale". There are also a "German legend" and an "Irish tale", and a Scots emphasis is not declared in the editor's preface; in fact, the frontmatter seems designed to assure continuity with the genre of the literary album. A dedicatory poem presents a female recipient, the "Lady of the Book", with this "album" as a "fair enclosure" uniting the Sister Arts in "quintessence of Poësy" (James Montgomery, "The First Leaf of an Album")--the same Romantic-era adaptation of ut pictura poesis as found in Relfe's volume 26. The frontispiece, "painted . . . expressly for this work", is a classical subject, Psyche and Cupid, just as volume 26 gravitated to Old Masters. (The artist, "J. Wood", was probably the history painter John Wood [1801-70], who had recently gained recognition at the Royal Academy for such works as Psyche Conveyed by Zephyrs to the Valley of Pleasure [1826; Sir John Soane's Museum, London]; see Cooper, "Wood, John [1801-1870]".). Nonetheless, a Caledonian thread runs through the annual, introduced early and prominently by a "landscape with ruins, designed and engraved for this work by John Martin". Rendered in Martin's typically sublime style, the picture overwhelms its homely pairing, the poem "Glen-Lynden: A Tale of Teviotdale" by the volume editor. (Pringle preferred the traditional name Teviotdale for the valley of the Teviot River near Kelso in Roxburghshire, where he was born. The name Glen Lynden, although used here for a fictional a Border glen, was in real life the name Pringle bestowed on the settlement in Cape Colony, South Africa, where he emigrated [Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 79].) Another plate on the theme of Scottish landscape with ruins features Campbell Castle in the Ochil Hills, drawn by George Arnald (1763-1841) and supported by a poem by David Macbeth Moir ("Delta", 1798-1851). The Ochils were known to Ruskin from the family's journeys north to Perth via Glenfarg. Pringle, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], 1-2, viii, 19-35, 143-44).
A figure piece on the Scottish theme is also a landscape

Illustration was key to the popularity of the annuals, as Elder would have realized from the precedent set by Ackermannʼs success. The first issue of Forget Me Not had featured a series of emblematic treatments of the twelve months, rendered in copper etching, along with verses by William Combe (1742–1823). Combe was well known as the author of The Tour of Doctor Syntax, in Search of the Picturesque (1812, 1820, 1821), a spoof illustrated by Thomas Rowlandson (1757–1827). This illustrated work ranked among the Ackermann firmʼs greatest best‐sellers (Ford, Ackermann, 52–60); and by employing Combe along with an illustrator on the new publication, Rudolph Ackermann was probably striving to maintain this popularity.

The success of Smith, Elderʼs venture appears to have hinged on a striking physical presentation of binding and printing and on the appeal of the illustrations. The first volume of Friendshipʼs Offering under the new proprietorship received a complimentary notice in The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction, the review focusing first on the “exterior, which is somewhat novel in taste, . . . by substituting for the usual paper covering [i.e., like the printed paper boards then covering the Forget Me Not], an elegantly embossed leather binding. This is altogether an improvement on the original plan, since the slight coverings of silk or paper is scarcely safe out of the drawing‐room or boudoir, and some of the contributions to the ‘annuals’ entitle them to a higher stand” (“Spirit of ‘The Annuals’ for 1828”, 418). By the “original plan”, the writer refers apparently to the binding used by Relfe, which consisted of glazed paper boards, printed with a decorative and typographic cover, in imitation of the binding used for the Forget Me Not (the latter already moving to silk; see Harris, Forget Me Not, 133). The new binding of Friendshipʼs Offering featured an arabesque design that was blind embossed into the full surface of the dark leather cover, with a lyre design blocked in gilt in the center of the front cover. As Eleanore Jamieson remarks in “The Binding Styles of the Gift Books and Annuals”, the arabesque pattern was regarded as a revival style hearkening to the early book, and the style was associated with Continental models (p. 11; and see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books).

The annuals dueled to be judged by their covers, the Ackermann firmʼs Forget Me Not having set an initial standard with its printed and glazed paper boards, cloth spine, and slipcase, later replaced by a silk cover (Ford, Ackermann, 65). Innovation and extravagance—or at least the appearance of extravagance—in bindings and engraved or lithographed front matter became characteristic of annuals, which used this immediate source of appeal to compete in a crowded market (see Faxon, Literary Annuals, xiv–xvi). Mechanization brought these material appeals within reach of the ordinary consumer; and mass‐produced fancy bindings in particular shifted traditional division of labor, since publishers took on the economic burden of bookbinding, which conventionally had been borne by the consumer. Harris also speculates that the annualsʼ elaborately embossed leather covers suggested the bindings of prayer books and bibles—the only other expensively bound stock that retailers typically offered over the counter (as opposed to cheap temporary bindings, to be replaced by the consumer). These “gospel‐like bindings” may have been meant “to convince the reading public of the wholesome value of the literature and engravings within” (Harris, Forget Me Not, 131, 133–34). Perhaps the comment in the Mirror of Literature that the sturdier cover of Friendshipʼs Offering matched its more substantial content inside, capable of subsisting beyond the ladyʼs boudoir, gestured at an audience that expanded to include, not just male readers, but the entire family gathered in the parlor.

The illustrated emblems of the months in Ackermannʼs Forget Me Not looked backward, however, to an eighteenth‐century tradition, rather than forward to new fashions. Copper engraving was soon to be displaced by more durable steel engraving, which would allow for much larger press runs; and the very inclusion of a monthly calendar hearkened to the gift annualʼs beginnings in the eighteenth‐century “pocket book” (see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books). The second volume of Forget Me Not, featured more varied pictorial scenes (albeit with mausoleums predominating), which were highlighted in the front matter by a list of plates that stood separately from the literary table of contents. The dual tables of contents—emblematic of the growing importance of visual culture in the early Victorian period—remained typical of annuals thereafter (see the facsimiles of Forget Me Not available in Harris, ed., “Forget Me Not” Archive).

This is how Forget Me Not stood in 1826–27, when Ruskinʼs aunt, Bridget Richardson (1783–1830), of Croydon, presented him with the volume for 1827, containing Monument at Verona, by Samuel Prout (1783–1852) (Ruskin, Works, 35:91). Engraved by Edward Finden (1791–1857), this plate would have numbered among the early steel engravings produced by the Finden brothers (see Hunnisett, Steel‐Engraved Book Illustration in England, 84–85). Ackermannʼs annual had now caught up with the technology of steel engraving for book illustration, which proved key to the success of all the annuals. As compared with softer copper, which soon lost its edge in repeated impressions, steel engraving made possible the mass production of images, and helped to satisfy the craving for pervasive, but affordable visual culture by the early‐Victorian middle class. These developments coincided with Alexander Elderʼs ambitions for Friendshipʼs Offering.

Smith, Elderʼs Friendshipʼs Offering benefited by these early, rapid developments in the annual as a commodity. Its binding was more sumptuous, and the engraving sharper and more consistent. To mark these improvements, Smith, Elder expanded the subtitle, from Relfeʼs Friendshipʼs Offering: A Literary Album to Friendshipʼs Offering: A Literary Album and Annual Remembrancer and A Literary Album, and Christmas and New Yearʼs Present. In 1833, the title changed again, the annual having absorbed another existing publication, Winterʼs Wreath, which had been published in Liverpool since 1828. This merger resulted in the title, Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath (so the title appears on the typeset title page; for a time, the engraved frontispiece with the earlier title remained in production). This latest title was in use when Ruskin first appeared in the annual, in the issue, Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath: A Christmas and New Yearʼs Present for MDCCCXXXV.

At the same time, a comparison of Smith, Elderʼs product with the volumes published by the annualʼs creator, Relfe, suggests that the new firm attempted to keep the interior uniform with earlier volumes, at least initially. As remarked about the 1826 volume edited by Hervey for Relfe, the annual was already responsive to the "poetic" sensibility that unified the sister arts during that period. . .
